title: MLB DFS Bargains: Friday 9/6
text:
Welcome to MLB DFS Bargains. We’ll split the analysis into three groups: very cheap, mid-tier, and expensive. A greater emphasis will be placed on the lower end of the price scale.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

Editor’s Note: Stay ahead of the competition from wire to wire with rankings, customizable projections, trade evaluator, exclusive columns and more in our Season Pass. And start using optimized lineups with our DFS Toolkit!

Scroll to continue with content Ad

All 15 games are a part of the evening slate. Keep an eye on possible rain in Boston and New York.

DIRT CHEAP BARGAINS

Joe Musgrove – SP – Pittsburgh Pirates (vs Cardinals)

The Cardinals offense isn’t especially ferocious against right-handed pitchers (92 wRC+). Nor is it entirely toothless. Despite his piddling price tag, Musgrove offers an interesting range of outcomes and upsides. Certainly, there are scenarios where he fails to last five innings and torpedoes your lineup. However, this downside exists with virtually all pitchers. Musgrove projects to perform like a mid-tier arm. Lately, his fastball velocity has perked up, and his swinging strike and strikeout rates have responded in kind. A quality start with five or more strikeouts would be quite valuable at this price.

Ryan McBroom – 1B/OF – Kansas City Royals (at Pablo Lopez)

Story continues

McBroom is a right-handed power hitter formerly in the Yankees organization. The 27-year-old was hopelessly buried on the depth chart. Now with the Royals, he’ll receive an extended look in preparation for 2020. He is a fly ball hitter with sufficient plate discipline and contact skills to help DFS participants out of the bargain bin. In 482 Triple-A plate appearances, he hit .315/.402/.574 with 26 home runs, a 12 percent walk rate and a 20.7 percent strikeout rate. He has a one-in-five chance to wallop a home run against Lopez and friends. Nor is he an all-or-nothing hitter. If he doesn’t homer, he may still wind up as an advantageous purchase.

Nick Solak – 2B/3B – Texas Rangers (at Dylan Bundy)

Solak delivered as promised yesterday, hammering a home run off a fly ball pitcher. Tonight’s opponent, Bundy, also has a long history of allowing fly ball contact and way too many home runs. Solak is once again in prime position to produce top DFS output at a very affordable price. The Solak versus Bundy matchup isn’t quite as fiery as yesterday’s pairing. However, since Bundy is less effective than Means, Solak should receive more support from other parts of the Rangers lineup.

Gavin Lux – 2B – Los Angeles Dodgers (vs Jeff Samardzija)

Lux has bounced around in the lineup since his call-up at the start of the month. There’s a chance he’ll hit near the top, although it’s more likely we’ll see him batting seventh or eighth. Wherever he lands, he’s so cheaply priced that it’ll be hard to pass him up. Lux is a line drive machine who uses the whole field to his advantage. He works counts and isn’t especially strikeout prone. While nobody should mistake him as a top power threat tonight, it’s very likely he’ll produce something useful for his owners.

Also Consider: Dillon Peters, Framber Valdez, Ty France, Josh Rojas, Josh Naylor, Mauricio Dubon, Jake Rogers, Phil Ervin, Randal Grichuk, Lorenzo Cain

MID-TIER MUST PLAYS

Manny Machado – SS/3B – San Diego Padres (vs Tim Melville)

Machado hasn’t quite lived up to expectations since signing with the Padres. In a year when everybody who’s anybody is on pace to hit 30 home runs, it feels like he’s limped along with the pack rather than taking the lead like a so-called superstar. However, a peek under the hood reveals business as usual. His plate discipline is unchanged and his batted ball profile is consistent with past seasons. To me, the obvious conclusion is that his style of hitting doesn’t receive many benefits from the juiced baseball. In any case, dissatisfaction does not mean he’s performing poorly. And he’s still excellently positioned to take advantage of a fly ball pitcher and terrible Rockies bullpen.

Also Consider: Hunter Renfroe, Victor Robles, Corey Seager

HIGH PRICED VALUES

Mike Trout – OF – Los Angeles Angels (at Lucas Giolito)

Trout is bizarrely cheap on one of the major platforms this evening. He’s priced more like an expensive mid-tier player than one of the top five hitters in the slate. I suppose we’re supposed to be worried about his matchup against Giolito, but it’s pretty clear that opposing pitcher has very little effect on Mr. Trout. As we all know, he does everything – a high average/OBP, oodles of run production, and a league-leading homer total. If you’re at all concerned about Trout versus Giolito, just remember the White Sox bullpen is highly exploitable.

Also Consider: Cody Bellinger, Aristides Aquino, Nelson Cruz, Alex Bregman, Jose Altuve, Max Kepler
description: Brad Johnson reviews his favorite MLB DFS bargain targets for Friday, September 6. (Getty Images)
